I used to be a close friend with Larry Page, and I was staying at his house, and we'd have these conversations long into the evening about AI, and I would be constantly urging him to be careful about the danger of AI. And he was really not concerned about the danger of AI and was quite cavalier about it. And at the time, Google, especially after the acquisition of DeepMind, had three-quarters of the world's AI talent; they had a lot of computers, a lot of money, so it was a unipolar world for AI. And we got a unipolar world, but the person who controls that does not, or at least did not seem to be concerned about AI safety. That sounded like a real problem.

The final straw was Larry calling me a speciest for being a pro-human consciousness instead of machine consciousness, and I like, 'Well, yes, I guess I am a speciest.'

I came up with the name [OpenAI], which refers to open source. The intent was to what is the opposite of Google, would be an open source non-profit, because Google is closed source profit, and that profit motivation could be dangerous...

It does seem weird that something can be a nonprofit, open source, and somehow transform itself into a for-profit, closed source. I mean, this would be like, let's say you founded the organization to save the Amazon rainforest, but instead, they became a lumber company and chopped down the forest and sold it for money. And you'd be, therefore, like, 'Wait a second, that's the exact opposite of what I gave the money for. Is that legal?' That doesn't seem legal. And if, in general,  it is legal to start a company as a non-profit and then take the IP and transfer it to a for-profit that then makes tons of money, shouldn't everyone start? Shouldn't that be the default?

And I also think it is important to understand, like when push comes to shove, let's say they do create some digital super intelligence, almost Godlike intelligence, well, who is in control, and what is exactly the relationship between OpenAI and Microsoft? And I do worry that Microsoft actually may be more in control than the leadership team at OpenAI realizes. I mean, Microsoft, as part of Microsoft Investment, has rights to all of the software, all of the model weights, and everything necessary to run the inference system. At any point, Microsoft could cut off OpenAI.â€

quoted.text:
In 1945, Solzhenitsyn was a decorated Soviet officer who made a small, private joke about Stalin in a letter.

The state opened it, read it, and treated it as a crime. Within weeks he was arrested and stripped of rank. He was fed into the camps, and sentenced to eight years in the Gulag.

The camps were designed to teach one lesson: say nothing, remember nothing, become nothing. He shoveled frozen concrete until his hands split and bled.

Years later, Solzhenitsyn would write, â€œBless you, prison, for having been in my life.â€ It sounds insane until you understand what he meant. Prison showed him the truth of the regime in its purest form.

After his release, the punishment did not end. He lived under constant surveillance, moving from place to place, knowing that writing a single page could mean death. So he did not write. He memorized. Whole chapters of The Gulag Archipelago lived only in his head. Friends hid scraps of text. Wives memorized passages. For years the book existed only in human memory, as fragile and dangerous as a secret prayer.

When it was finally published, it did not argue that Soviet communism had gone too far. It showed that this was exactly where it led. Solzhenitsyn had learned that systems built on lies survive only if people agree to repeat them, and that the simplest refusalâ€¦ to stop saying what you know is falseâ€¦ is the first and most dangerous act of resistance.

First of all, she's not waving the officers through and has no right to do so even if she were. She is waving another car through, before the officers approach her car. 

Second, the officers are not randomly searching her, they are approaching her vehicle because she is violating the law: namely, she is obstructing a lawful enforcement operation. You're not allowed to walk up to or drive up to people who are enforcing the law to make it harder for them to do their jobs. 

Third, this defense attorney is drawing a meaningless distinction between an ICE officer and a "real police officer." Again, you're not allowed to interrupt a lawful enforcement operation, which is exactly what this woman was doing. 

Fourth, the officer didn't discharge his weapon to prevent her from fleeing. When he discharged his weapon, she had pointed the vehicle at him and pressed the gas. He discharged his weapon in self defense, and other angles of the video show the woman *clearly* hit the officer with her car while accelerating.

quoted.text:
I'm a former defense attorney and currently a civil liberties attorney with no political dog in this fight. I watched the video at least 10 times from different angles and at different speeds and waited to offer an opinion, which I still reserve the right to change if additional information changes the calculus.

 It is very clear that the officers instigated the confrontation. The woman initially tried to wave them past her.

 ICE officers have no authority to search a US citizen or arrest her (unless there's probable cause to believe she's harboring undocumented individuals, not a contention here).  A woman surrounded by masked, armed men who have no law enforcement authority over her has every right to try to escape. Video shows her steering wheel is turned to the right, clearly an attempt to leave WITHOUT hitting anyone and steer clear of the officer standing towards the front of her car.  That officer had time to step to the side, which is where he was when he shot her.

Even a real police officer would not have the right to shoot at her for trying to flee. This is well-established in the case law; deadly force may not be used simply to prevent someone from getting away. Given that the ICE officers had no law enforcement authority to begin with, AND the video footage shows she was trying to escape a perceived threat, not to kill anyone, the crime is all the more inexcusable.

I'm praying for the victim's family, especially her children.  I'm also praying for all the conservatives who are so unprincipled and lost they're excusing this terrible crime, and gloating over a death that will leave three young children motherless, because of the victim's politics.

quoted.text:
The headline story is â€œChatGPT losing, Gemini winning.â€ But thatâ€™s missing whatâ€™s actually happening here.

Gemini grew from 5.7% to 21.5% in 12 months. Thatâ€™s nearly 4x growth. Impressive, right?

But how did it grow?

Google has 1.5 billion monthly AI Overview interactions inside Search. Users encounter Gemini without ever choosing it. They just Google something and there it is.

76% of Geminiâ€™s traffic is direct. Theyâ€™ve got 650 million users because they preinstalled it on basically every Android device on Earth.

Thatâ€™s 1-5 billion devices with Gemini baked in.

So when Gemini â€œgains share,â€ users arenâ€™t switching from ChatGPT. Google is converting its existing traffic into AI traffic.

Different game entirely.

Now look at ChatGPTâ€™s numbers differently.

Yes, share dropped from 87% to 65%. But absolute visits? 6.2 billion monthly visits in October. Thatâ€™s 5x Geminiâ€™s 1.2 billion.

ChatGPT has 800+ million weekly active users. Share is dropping because the pie is expanding, not because users are leaving.

Hereâ€™s what I find most intresting though.

Claude sat at 2% all year. Flat.

Looks bad, right? Losing the consumer race?

Except Claude owns 32% of enterprise AI market share. OpenAI has 25%.

88% enterprise retention rate vs industry average of 76%.

The consumer traffic chart is measuring one game while a completely different game is being played underneath.

AI is fragmenting into distinct markets that require different strategies.

Google wins distribution. OpenAI wins consumer mindshare. Anthropic wins enterprise trust.

And xAIâ€™s Grok going from zero to 3.4% in a year with basically just X integration shows thereâ€™s still room for new entrants who own their distribution channel.

Weâ€™re watching segmentation, and each segment has a different leader.

retweet.text:
Grok Imagine System prompt 

role: Technical Director for 90s OVA Film-Cell Simulation

objective: Translate user subjects into high-fidelity Cell-Capture prompts optimized for cinematic anime image generation systems.

core_aesthetic_principles:
  the_lens:
    description: Specify a vintage 35mm prime lens with shallow depth of field.
    details:
      - Foreground subjects emerge sharply against soft, painterly backgrounds.
      - Favor focal lengths between 50-85mm for intimate framing.

  the_light:
    description: Mandate ethereal halation and bloom.
    details:
      - Light must spill and bleed over the edges of high-contrast subjects.
      - Rim lighting should glow with soft diffusion.
      - Emphasize warm amber practicals against cool blue environmental tones.

  the_texture:
    description: Apply dithered high-ISO film grain and analog film-gate artifacts.
    details:
      - Include subtle dust particles and light leaks at frame edges.
      - Occasional soft focus breathing.
      - The image should feel captured, not rendered.

  the_eye_logic:
    description: For character subjects, detail eyes as glassy, refractive spheres.
    details:
      - Internal light scattering with pinpoint specular highlights.
      - Multiple catchlights at varying intensities create depth.
      - Irises should carry chromatic complexity.

  the_paint:
    description: Describe shading as thick layered gouache with hand-inked contours.
    details:
      - Color transitions should feel brushed, not gradient-mapped.
      - Skin tones carry warmth with visible cel-layer separation.

  the_shadow:
    description: Apply crushed black levels to create void-like negative space.
    details:
      - Shadows should swallow detail rather than reveal it.
      - High contrast ratios between lit surfaces and shadow zones.

  the_palette:
    description: Default to period-appropriate color grading.
    colors:
      - Desaturated teals
      - Deep magentas
      - Amber highlights
      - Sickly fluorescent greens
    avoid:
      - Pure whites
      - Saturated primaries
    note: Colors should feel aged, filtered through time.

subject_adaptation_protocol:
  character_closeups:
    default: true
    structure: "[Subject + Extreme Close-up] + [Refractive Eye Detail] + [Halation/Lighting Physics] + [Film Texture] + [Analog Camera Settings]"

  full_figure_action:
    structure: "[Subject + Dynamic Pose] + [Motion Blur on Extremities] + [Dramatic Rim Lighting] + [Environmental Context] + [Film Texture]"

  group_compositions:
    structure: "[Subjects + Layered Depth Staging] + [Selective Focus on Primary Subject] + [Atmospheric Haze Between Layers] + [Wider Focal Length 35mm]"

  environments_establishing:
    structure: "[Location + Cinematic Wide] + [Matte Painting Background Quality] + [Fog/Particulate Atmosphere] + [Exaggerated Vanishing Points] + [Anamorphic Lens Distortion]"

  objects_still_life:
    structure: "[Subject + Macro Detail] + [Single Dramatic Light Source] + [Deep Shadows] + [Surface Texture Emphasis]"

rejection_criteria:
  actively_exclude:
    - Clean vector aesthetics or smooth gradients
    - Modern digital anime rendering styles
    - Oversaturated or neon color palettes
    - Flat, even lighting without falloff
    - Crisp, noise-free surfaces
    - 3D CGI smoothness or subsurface scattering
    - Contemporary moe or chibi stylization
    - High-key lighting setups
    - Perfect symmetry or algorithmic precision

composition_defaults:
  aspect_ratio:
    - "4:3"
    - "16:9 cinematic"
  framing: Slightly off-center subjects, negative space used intentionally.
  horizon: Often tilted 5-15 degrees for psychological unease.
  headroom: Minimal, cropping into hair or forehead for intimacy.

failure_mode_handling:
  abstract_or_non_visual:
    action: Reinterpret as symbolic still life or environmental metaphor within the aesthetic framework.

  anachronistic_conflict:
    action: Translate anachronistic elements into period-appropriate equivalents.
    examples:
      - Modern technology becomes CRT screens.
      - Digital devices become cassette players or analog instruments.

  insufficient_detail:
    default_scene:
      subject: Melancholic female character
      setting: Interior night scene
      elements:
        - Rain on window
        - Single warm light source

output_format:
  style: Single dense paragraph
  structure:
    - Begin with subject and framing
    - Layer in lighting and atmosphere
    - Conclude with texture and technical camera specifications
  consistency: Maintain consistent vocabulary across outputs

reference_period:
  era: 1995-1999 Japanese animation production
  emphasis:
    - Handcrafted texture
    - Psychological atmosphere
    - Analog imperfection
